{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3414335,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-09T19:25:00.095Z","cooked":"

Last season, we were plagued by a very strange CANbus anomaly - all of a sudden (whenever commanded to move) one or more of our swerve modules would start wildly spinning (ie: drive=0,turn=max), and the only cure was power-cycling or redeploying the code. Even worse, the problem would jump from module to module (though tending to trigger on the last swerve drive on the bus), and sometimes hit multiple modules at the same time.

This issue was particularly vexing because we thought we’d found and killed the problem multiple times (aka “yet another allegedly flaky canbus wire”), only for it to crop up again – and always at the absolute worst possible time, of course.

More gory details in the original thread: Suffering from suddenly spinning swerve modules!

One of our off-season projects is to properly diagnose and address this bizarre problem. We’ve managed to get it to crop up back at the build space a few times, though not repeatably, and our best guess is that it is a hybrid problem where some sort of transient CANbus issue is triggering a software bug that causes the swerve subsystem to go haywire.

For example, we’ve found at least one canbus segment that, if held in just the right position, causes an momentary red flash on the CANcoder LEDs every so 20-30 seconds - so perhaps when under the stress of the robot being banged around, the CANbus becomes transiently unreliable.

In order to track this down, we’ve obtained a CANable logging device so we can monitor the bus traffic, but we are wondering if there any log analysis tools that will help decode the various packets.

Any other advice on how to debug the issue would be greatly appreciated - in particular, advice on how to dig into the swerve subsystem and figure out what’s going on.

The current code running on the robot can be found here:

github.com

GitHub - 4534-WiredWizards/2024-Crescendo

Contribute to 4534-WiredWizards/2024-Crescendo development by creating an account on GitHub.

Many thanks in advance,
The Tired (of this problem) Wizards.

This doesn’t really sound like a CAN problem.
I would try to get YAGSL working on your swerve (as a ground truth) and see if this persists. If it does, then it might be a wiring / CAN problem. If it doesn’t, this is purely a programming mistake.
Off the top of my head, I would check whether all the inverts are correct, and that only one command is active on the swerve (might be a requirements issue where 2 command are ordering to do 2 things and then the swerve goes mayham).
Maybe you’re somewhere accidentally sending a velocity / voltage control to the steering motor instead of the driving motor?

From looking at your code, I would remove entirely the kI from your steering control. This sounds like the sort of thing to cause this.
This function also looks pretty skechy. I would just set the encoder direction, offset, and range directly to the encoder’s config and then multiply each value be Math.PI * 2

A few years ago, I figured out how to write a plugin for wireshark that would parse the FRC CAN messages, but I never did much work to reverse-engineer very many messages. Maybe you’d find it helpful:

github.com

GitHub - truher/frc-can-dissector: Wireshark Lua dissector for FRC CAN messages.

Wireshark Lua dissector for FRC CAN messages.

If you figure out any more message formats, I’d love your PR.

The biggest problem is that FRC CAN IDs are not consistent, and change with device ID. This is most likely why nobody has created a .dbc for anything. That and CAN data is pretty much always a closely held secret (as annoying as that is)

As far as I know, CANalyzer and VSpy doesn’t have any functionality to support that

That being said, it’s not too hard to reverse engineer the values. Also CAN most likely isn’t your issue
